items.abstract: <jats:p>Quantifying the constitutive nonlinearity parameter<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M1"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math>in fluids is of key interest for understanding ultrasonic propagation and its wide implications in medical and industrial applications. However, current methods for ultrasonically measuring it show large limitations in that the signal is only valid at a reduced and unjustified spatial range away from the transducer. This is not consistent with the fact that<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M2"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math>should be constant everywhere in the fluid and independently of the ultrasonic experimental setup. To overcome this, the nonlinear wave propagation equations are rigorously derived and the ensuing differential equation is numerically solved. As a second contribution, the experimental and model information sources are treated under the information theory context to probabilistically reconstruct<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M3"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math>, providing not only its value, but also the degree of confidence on it given both sources of data. This method is satisfactorily validated testing the repeatability of<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M4"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math>in water varying distances, energies, frequencies, and transducer setups, yielding values compatible with<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="M5"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>β</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math>= 3.5.</jats:p>
title: Logical Inference for Model-Based Reconstruction of Ultrasonic Nonlinearity

items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
<jats:p>The paper has employed a three-factor model of constraints, which differentiates intrapersonal, interpersonal and structural. The study was carried out on a sample of N = 981 adult residents of Poland. The three most common barriers constraining attendance at attractions were identified: availability, high entrance fees and lack of time. The constraints were found to be related to a number of socio-demographic characteristics, such as gender, age, education, size of place of residence and household income per capita. Three market segments limited by similar constraints and showing similar attraction attendance behaviour were identified with their socio-demographic characteristics.</jats:p>
title: Constraints To Attendance At Visitor Attractions: The Case Of Museums, Zoos And Botanic Gardens
